The mongolian beef was good too, and it mixed well with the rice.  Just a tad salty.  What Americanized Asian food isn't nowadays though -_-...

Service was fine, though it's obvious from observing the service of others that the staff has a lot to learn.  Still, I got my food in a timely manner.

Oh, and if the owners/staff are reading this, please, for the love of god, close the front door.  It's absolutely freezing in there in this winter weather. bbrrrrr

Ok, for a FiDi asian restaurant, it's 4 stars.  Anywhere else and this place is lackluster.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Food is 3-4 stars, but for combo of location and large servings leans towards a 4.  I usually get beef congee (jook, rice porridge) - folks into authentic can get preserved egg and pork [all these years in the Bay Area, still haven't got the taste for gelatinous eggs in my food :^( ] or I get spicy beef soup (pho).  Tried the five spice and grilled pork, and they are fine too.

Crowded during 12-1pm (lunch), so if a big group (2+) gotta go early (before 11:45am).
author: Chris D.

description: They have the best spicy pho, and always get the seafood one (it's not the freshest seafood, but what do you expect for less than $10?).  I only get this pho here,  I wouldn't try anything else.  It's not the cleanest place around, I have heard of complaints.  But it's a pho place, I think they are all the same, cleanliness wise.  Just order the pho, and you are good to go.
author: Nicole S.

description: I love their Spicy Beef Noodle Soup. Best hangover food ever. I'm also a fan of their Katsu Chicken & their fried egg rolls. I come here often for lunch and I will continue to do so. Staff is friendly, food is good so they'll be seeing me often.
author: Joane B.

description: I had the Vietnamese pork sandwich and my wife had a spicy noodle soup with chicken. Both were great, as was the Vietnamese coffee. We'd come here again.
author: Ran M.

description:
A-OK.

This place is upstairs and then a big open space.
On one back wall is the register and menu. There's a fairly comprehensive selection of food, enough to cover all bases. Prices are also very reasonable for this location.

The place has no character, the lighting isn't great but then I guess you don't come here for that. Quick and cheap this place is tops.

Food quality is ok. The food is more than edible but my beef chow fun was more like beef bean sprouts. Why? I am sure there were more bean sprouts than hor fun on my plate. Shame as it's pretty good otherwise. Beef is tender, I feel there is msg present but you will only find that out later on!!

Spicy chicken noodle soup, broth was ok, chicken was tasty but by no means the best we've had. It's good for 3 stars overall. It is pretty fast on the plus side but a little lacking in the food quality on the downside.

The one restroom is hilarious. There's a key on the outside with a strong attached to it. You have to open the door and go in with the key or anyone could just open the door and come in?! Then you have to put the key back or no one else would ever be able to get in. Odd.
author: Nick L.

description:
What I like about this place is that it's spacious, clean, and affordable! Sure, it's not the best tasting food but good enough to fill you up for lunch for less than $10.

While I was eating my Vietnamese sandwich, I looked around at what other people were having and everything looked BIG, they are not shady on the portions.
author: Emmie N.

description: I come here a few times a month to get my Pho fix, but it's just ok. Just enough to get me through. Not bad, just not great.  The rice plates are decent as well. "Phood Nation"
author: Sean J.

description: Pho and 5 spice chicken, the only 2 dishes I ever get here. Hkk is a good option if you're looking for some solid Asian food in the financial district. The service is quick, food is aiite, and the prices are reasonable for downtown sf.
author: Alex K.

description:
This is hidden away on the second floor, occupying the space that used to be All Seasons.  The review is for lunch only.  

They're fast, even during the lunch rush.  Their specialties are their Vietnamese dishes, especially their soups; they still offer a small Chinese / pan-Asian menu, which you should avoid, and I am not factoring into this review.

Their soups are very, very good - five star worthy.  I especially recommend their spicy vegetable soup and their "Special beef soup".  For $8, in this location, they're both a very good deal.  

This review is part of a series on lunch places near my office.
author: Zachary R.

description: Haven't been back in this part of town in a long time and ordered the won ton soup.  Delicous, delicous, delicous!!
author: Liz H.

description: Good pho, but probably a bit more expensive than it should be. I had the spicy seafood pho and it had more seafood in it than most other pho I have had. My order was to go and I was walking out the door within 5 minutes at lunch time on a Wednesday. The place used to be a shabby Asian restaurant but it has been renovated and re-purposed in the last couple of years.
author: Daniel G.

description: This is a good option for Vietnamese or Chinese food for lunch in the financial district. Their prices are reasonable and the food is good. Keep in mind, this is a quick lunch spot type of place so it is nothing fancy in terms of decor or service. I recommend any of the beef phos, wonton soup, vermicelli bowls, and the preserved egg congee. I've had the chicken pho and spicy seafood noodle soups before, but those weren't as good.
author: Jessie L.

description: Ehhh....ordered the porridge. It was a very big bowl. Nothing special or mind blowing...
author: Tikisha O.

description: I was staying across the street at the Hyatt with some colleagues when we needed a quick lunch and found this place.  Hong's is one of those out of the way places that aren't visually simulating or impressive but have rock solid food that will surprise you.  Three of the five colleagues who came to lunch wiht me were Asian, and ALL of us loved the food. We all ordered different dishes and all of it was very good. While you don't want to come here for fine dining if you're looking for very good Asian at a very reasonable price I would recommend this place in a heartbeat.  Enjoy....
author: Ben C.

description: Super fast service, good portions and really good affordable pho! Don't know why it's not more packed in here
author: Kim H.

description: Service was great, really sweet people which is why its hard for me to write this. but the pho was very sub par, tasted bland/not like real pho brother. i had the pho with meat balls. meats balls were a bit chewy/fatty for my taste. and i have had a lot of pho in my life...i know whati m talkin about.
author: Thach N.

description: I feel like I'm nit-picking but I just had to update my review.  I dined here recently instead of ordering take-out and to my dismay I had a much different experience.  First of all when you ask for water instead of ordering a drink they don't bring it to your table, I suppose it's self-service.  Second of all, after patrons leave they don't clean the tables.  I sat in a corner for 45 minutes observing the workers and they did not clean a single table.  They just picked off the food from the table with tissues, yuck.  It made me question what else in the restaurant they're not cleaning.  Very grossed out.  My table was oily and slimey and now I know why.
author: Amber R.

description: Great location.  Food could be better, though.  Also, this restaurant does not make notations for spicy foods on the menu so for those who do not like hot/spicy foods, it's trial and error.
author: Virginia C.

description:
There used to be a Chinese place here, which I truly miss.  I started coming here as soon as they opened....and have been disappointed every time.  I only get take out since when I get released from my job, it's usually between 2pm and 4pm and the whole place has always been completely empty except for the service girls.  The girls are always very sweet.  However, everything I've ever gotten from here has been sub-par, even for Chinese food.  Plus it's always taken them close to 45 mins. to get the food to me, even just a cold salad.  There are other places to eat around this area so I've stopped going here.  Plus there's this stairway you have to climb to get up there, and then you have to climb down it and it's kind of steep; my old knees aren't always happy to do that climb anymore.  If I want Vietnamese, I do the 5-6 block walk to Sai's.  If I want Chinese I'll go the Henry's Hunan, another easy walk.  They could do do much more with this restaurant but they haven't which is so disappointing.

March 2015.  So, it's been a while and I'm still going here.  It's not Chinese, it's Vietnamese!  They have some Chinese dishes but it's done Vietnamese style.  It makes a difference to know this.  Ok, I find their pho has a kind of anise taste to it.  Not a bad thing, just different.  They also do a wor won ton.  Their rice dishes are ok.  I still don't understand that with all these Asian vegetables we have available in this city why they have to resort to broccoli--too many Vietnamese eateries do this.  Their dishes would be so much better if they'd use napa or Chinese broccoli at least.  And the keep removing entrees from their blackboard.  The food is good since there isn't another Vietnamese eatery real closeby (the bun mi shop in Embarco 5 sucks! threw out 2 sandwiches from there (I think it's called LIttle Saigon?)).  The other pho place, Soup Junkie, on Market has closed.  Oh me, oh my.  Good thing I have a few good Vietnamese places near home, just wish I could get my fix while at work too.  Oh, but Hong Kee will do.  The young women are all very nice.
author: Kai T.

description: A OK place. Nothing stands out. Pho soup is too plain, and sandwiches aren't that good either.
author: Kihoon Y.

description:
I suspect a lot of the other dishes are fine, but I was really disappointed by my chicken pho. Cheap, nasty chicken, remarkably greasy broth, and the curious addition of tomatoes and cabbage.  I wouldn't complain if it were cheaper, but for $8 I should get nice tender chicken breast, not consistently chewy gristle, and a broth that relied more on fresh flavors than grease. It almost had a Ramen quality to it, very far from homemade.

To be fair, the service was fast and friendly and the place seemed popular.
author: Mat S.

description:
went there today.  ordered spicy mixed vegetable soup under "vegetarian choices."  brought back to office.  it smelled fishy, like it contained fish.  I called.  they confirmed it has fish sauce in it. i bought it back.

i am a vegetarian but not an angry one.  i assume that an item under "vegetarian choices" is vegetarian.  this is bullshit.
author: pete c.

description: Easy, convenient lunch spot in the heart of the Embaradero Center area. Definitely go a little before noon to beat the Fi-Di lunch crowd. Lots of variety to choose from. I usually like to get the special five spice chicken with fried imperial rolls. Definitely affordable.
author: Phillip D.

description: Meh pretty much sums it up. I thought it was the All Seasons with a badly needed remodel but it appears to be Vietnamese. I had the wonton noodle soup. The broth was OK, the noodles OK but the shrimp wontons.... the meat they bundled around the shrimp tasted like sausage. Not sure I'll be going back here.
author: Hitomi B.

description: I like the Vietnamese sandwiches and BBQ pork vermicelli they have. It's pretty decent and the prices are ok. It's not as cheap as other Vietnamese places in inner richmond but it's good for the financial district. It's also much better than the old chinese place that use to be here before! They also accept GoPaGo!
author: David L.

description: This Vietnamese/Chinese breakfast and lunch restaurant serves a variety of food (congee, dim sum, banh mi, salads, pho, vermicelli bowls, etc.), but I've only tried the pho so far.  The takeaway packaging is definitely similar to Hi-Tea's with handy tupperwares (one for soup, and a separate bowl for the noodles), and all the condiments you need.  The combination beef pho definitely satisfied my noodle soup craving, but the broth was pretty lackluster.  For dining in, the seating area is really large, so it's great for groups or eating on your own.  I'd come again only because of the convenience factor, but not because the food is spectacular.
author: Audacity L.

description: This place sucks. I arrived upon opening, ordered, and received my meal quickly but -- if I have to add 2tbsp of sriracha and hoisin to the broth then it isn't good broth. I tasted it beforehand and it was flavorless and watery. The noodles were really starchy, the brisket was undercooked and too fatty, and they skimp out on tendon and tripe.
author: Zooey I.

description: Hong Kee & Kim adds much needed variety to the Asian cuisine around the Embarcadero.  The Vietnamese and Chinese cuisine here is authentic, albeit unspectacular and rather salty.  The restaurant interior is somewhat dim and nondescript, though it is clean and orderly.  Given the few dinner alternatives and the early closing times of other neighborhood restaurants, Hong Kee is certainly a welcome addition.
author: Chris T.

description: Close to work, the prices aren't FiDi ridiculous & they conveniently have jook & a bowl of pho when need be for my yearnings. 2 pluses for me.  They have authentic jook with salted pork & my black eggs.  Yes people I am one of "those" .  Secondly, pho that they allow me to customize to my fave tendon & tripe ONLY.  And get this there's no extra charge for this or that when I tweak my hot bowl o' beef noodle soup..Uh Hem *Pho Hoa* I will not be paying you another visit anytime soon.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
tried hong kee today after finding out they'd just opened. The menu and pricing is what I've been looking for near the office.

Got a bowl of pho that was so-so. The soup was a bit hollow, if you eat pho you know what i mean. My beef also had a slightly weird taste to it - nonetheless i finished it anwyays. I'm hoping the owners read the reviews and adjust their recipes accordingly. BTW this place is chinese owned (I know because im chinese too, ha) 

A coworker got the grilled chicken + egg roll over rice. He said the chicken was great, but the egg roll needs work. The fish sauce was a bit sweet too. 

All in all I'd go again, we still havnt had the vermicelli yet and theyve got a long list of menu items. The space is big and the service was fast, plusses for the work lunch crowd. Both our items were less than $8 so that was also a plus.
author: pato m.

description: This place is a gem in the fidi.  It is cheap, fast, and delicious.  I had the pho ga (chicken noodle soup), and it was super tasty.  The broth didn't taste msg-saturated like some other pho places -- it was a nice change.  It's a good alternative to Sai's.
author: tiff g.

description: To go with my "it's really not a cold, *cough*" I needed serious chicken noodle soup with wontons (chinese style, but not greasy).  I got exactly what I was craving and envisioning.  So happy I can walk over easily during lunch to try more.  Noodle soup season is coming!
author: Olivia M.

description: This is my go-to place whenever I want Chinese/Vietnamese food within walking distance from my office in the Financial District. Honestly, the pho can't compare to some other places that one might go to in a more Asian neighborhood, but for the location and price, I'll choose this place over some other nearby shops anytime. I really like their spicy beef noodle soup as well for the days I'd like a bit more of a kick to my food. The preserved egg and pork porridge is good, though some may feel it runs on the watery side, but I don't like overly chunky and thick porridge either. I think the five spice chicken and the grilled pork chop with rice are both pretty yummy and well portioned. So I give this place a 4/5 star based on price and flavor for the location it's at. There are definitely other restaurants that are better if you go farther out in SF or down over to San Jose, but this place has treated me well for many lunches and they have quick service.
author: Becky C.

description: If this is actually the new Hi Tea everybody with low stars is on f*&$ing drugs. Hi tea is amazing. I am coming tomorrow. Spicy chicken noodle soup all around. Go to hell, vegetarians, you obviously dont know whats good for you..... or you wouldnt be a vegetarian.
author: Emily H.

description: Solid vegetarian pho, loved the spicy broth. Filling and comforting, and especially good for the price point.
author: R. O.

description:
Lunchtime with a few friends near work, and came to find that they have my favorite item "Beef with eggrolls in Vermicelli noodle".  It was a fair amount of food and the price isn't that bad for financial district.  My friend had the spicy broth noodle and she actually liked it too.  

This place actually wasn't bad at all.  I think I'll make this luncheon once a week.
author: Susie N.

description:
Hong Kee & Kim occupies an impressive space on the second floor of its building, impressive because it's spacious and bright, and altogether too nice for the type of establishment they're trying to run. Props for being one of the few places in FiDi where you can, without too much trouble, find a table for a moderate-sized group. In fact, I think they're under-utilizing their space, as only about half of the area has tables. The other half is given over to people in line and waiting for their to-go orders.

I found my beef banh mi as tasty as any other I've had, and filling. At $5, it's also one of the cheapest meals to be had around my office. Unfortunately, my friends' entrees didn't look too good. One of them got some chicken and rice dish that came with very suspicious-looking eggrolls. They looked like eggrolls that would come with your Swanson TV dinner. I would say check this place out, but think carefully before placing your order.
author: Angela X.

description: First time getting lunch from this place. The food I ordered was great; turned out to be way better than expected. I will be buying ongoing lunches @ this place. You do have to provide adequate time to get your food because they only cook when ordered. For to go's, you should call and order before heading over.
author: poogs d.

description: Amazing. Went here not expecting much, but the food was delicious! It was carefully prepared, well presented, and tasty. And it was affordable. Definitely coming back when we're in the area. Service was super nice, too. :)
author: Erin P.

description:
Given the location and price of the food, this place is pretty unbeatable.  
Yes, the pho isn't the greatest... but probably the best you'll find in the area, so just deal with it.  Awesome comfort food.  

This place is definitely my go to spot for their GRILLED PORK SANDWICH (definite must try) and their milk tea tapioca is very consistent.  

Best to just call in to place your order and then go and pay to avoid having to wait.
author: Emily L.

description:
do i seriously have to ask you for extra bean sprouts and lemon each time? 1 star for skimpping so much on the food. 

And seriously, do u know what I extremely hate about restaurants.?... Restaurants who don't leave their napkins out... where do u think we are? Vietnam? 

Here's a tip for ALLLL you restaurant owners... conserving a few hundred dollers on napkins really pisses the customers off b/c they have to ask u for napkins. That's no way to do business, if you're smart, you'll notice that restaurants with good reviews all have their napkins out.. so, won't u just not be cheap? u will earn more reputation (money), if u stop being cheap,
author: Mr. AzzHole A.

description: This pretty great little place for lunch.  The Pho was great and chicken noodle dish was delicious as well.  It's convenient if you work or live near the financial district and usually the wait isn't too bad.  I'd recommend it for visitors as it's not too touristy.
author: Carly H.

description: Theres a good variety of Asian food and Vietnamese sandwiches, lots of indoor seating, and they take credit cards. Food is alright.
author: Melody L.

description: awesome breakfast combo.  Fresh good congee and dim sum for $6.  Price - quality - location are all good. Self serve not a big deal
author: Mia W.

description:
This place is pretty good for the location and price. Came here at the suggestion of a coworker and was pleasantly surprised. If you don't pay attention when you walk by, you can miss the entrance as the restaurant signage on the building is on the second floor. 

It's pretty obvious that they didn't spend much thought or $$ on the TIs but food is what I'm reviewing. I got the lunch special - 5 spice chicken and 2 spring rolls over rice for $7.87 including tax. The food was slightly bland but I don't like the salt bomb taste of most Asian fastfood-type restaurants so it was good. The order came out pretty quick so no complaints here.

All in all, it's more like a eat quick and get out, rather than enjoy the ambiance (don't have none) type of establishment. They have quite a few selections for the lunch items so I will probably return.
author: Shikshin G.

description: Vegetarian "pho"!!!  That actually has flavor!  Make sure you ask them to "make it vegetarian" if that concerns you.  The ladies who work the counter are always courteous and on top of it, even during the mad lunch rush.  I've only gotten my food to go, but the wait has always been manageable.  Also, you can call ahead.
author: Jorie P.

description: Much, MUCH nicer than the chinese restaurant that was here before!  I went here today for the first time and overall the service and menu was good, but the spicy chicken pho was not all that great.  It was a strange color with not a lot of flavor (and NOT spicy) and had lettuce and tomatoes and other random ingredients in it.  Not a fan.  In all fairness, my co-worker had the pork with rice,  which she really enjoyed.  I will definitely be trying something else next time.
author: Justine S.

description: I wanted to love Hong Kee but I couldn't. I had spicy pho which was underwhelming. I also ordered pork buns once and it took an hour after they blamed it on my friend for ordering the last one (huh??). Another time they forgot to make my food. Every time I come here something goes wrong. It just wasn't meant to be.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
The new Hi-Tea!!!!

I am in love with their Spciy Chicken Noodle Soup! It's perfect for a cold winter day in SF. Just the right amount of spicy.

Grilled pork with vermicelli and egg rolls are super delish as well.

So glad I found this place, I come here atleast twice a week now.
author: Anon Y.

description: Decided to to try this place after hearing from a friend that these were opened by the same owners as Hi-Tea. Had their Spicy Beef Noodle Soup.. they gave a lot of noodles, not so much beef.. the beef was not the rare beef ones you would have with pho, but instead the ones you would have when eating chow-mein..I'm ok with that, but would prefer to have rare beef instead.. also, the soup was really spicy which was great!
author: Linda Y.

description: The food is all right.  But our order took over 30 minutes to come.  And when one of the plates came, it was wrong.
author: Margaret H.

description: This place is right next to my work and I had been here a few times when it was All Seasons Chinese.  I had the spicy chicken noodle soup and it was just what I needed for a cold day.  The broth is delicious and the portions are pretty big.  It is definitely one of my favorite go-to noodle soups for lunch and I plan on coming back again.
author: Connie D.

description: Good, high volume, no frills Asian restaurant.  You probably want to leave your skittish non-Asian friends back at the office though.  Keep aesthetic standards low, but food overall tastes good.
author: Jon S.

description: I hate to write such a poor rating for a new Asian fast-food restaurant in the financial district.  I think the concept of a multi-Asian food restaurant, mostly Vietnamese and Chinese food, is great, especially in the finacial district, but the execution was not so good.  I waited for at least 25 minutes to get my take-out order, chicken chow mein, and there were two other people who had ordered the same item waiting before me.  After hearing the person behind the counter say that the wait would be at least 15 minutes for chicken chow mein to another customer, I asked them how much longer my order would take.  You would think that if so many people were ordering the same item, the cook would make a bigger batch to give all the people waiting for that dish.  They finally came out with my order, but the other person who had been waiting before I ordered had been waiting for 35 minutes already, and he was still waiting after I left.  The food was not too good either.  The chicken was tender but the noodles had a very smokey burnt flavor to them.  The other disturbing thing is there was a piece of hair in the bag my food came.  Going forward, if I am in the mood for Asian food, I will just look to Pho Hoa or Stone Korean Kitchen which is fairly fast to take out and tastes good.
author: Lisa M.
